newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary's Titasz reorganises, sees cost savings.
newsitem.headline: Hungary's Titasz reorganises, sees cost savings.

text.p: Hungarian electricity distributor Tiszantuli Aramszolgaltato Rt (Titasz) expects to save 600 million forints a year after a restructuring scheduled to be finished by 1998, Hungarian news agency MTI said.

MTI quoted Heinz Klinger, chairman of Titasz's supervisory board and Janos Csato, the company's CEO, as saying that the main change was that the company's three-level structure was being reorganised to two levels, by closing regional offices.
Titasz, 49.23 percent owned by Germany's Isar-Amperwerke, held a news conference before its annual shareholders meeting, in its east Hungarian headquarters of Debrecen.

The company closed last year with a loss of 2.5 billion forints, despite a four percent growth in sales of electricity over the year 1995, MTI said, adding that higher sales enabled Titasz to reduce its losses by 200 million forints from 1995.
Its sales revenues rose 27 percent to 26.3 billion forints, it added.
